attributes.title: 1. Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
After stock reconciliation it was found that physical stock counted for all stock items matched with the book balance except for the following items which had a minimal variation: -

v  Bread stock had a negative variation of 450 loaves. The short fall was recovered from the supervisors responsible.

v  Packing Materials had a cumulative variation of 656 pieces.

v  Gunny bags for 25kg and 50Kg had negative variance of -4 pieces and 14 pieces respectively.

The table below illustrates the findings
attributes.recommendation: The branch management needs to tighten bread control, poly bags and gunny bags control to reduce the variation noted.
attributes.effect: The significant variances observed in stock reflects a weak internal controls. The shortage of 450 loaves of bread, valued at Ksh. 23,850.00, highlights the potential for financial loss, stock pilferage, or misreporting if corrective actions are not taken.

value: We will follow up on the stock items with variations to ensure those variations are eliminated.

Bread short fall was recovered from the supervisors.

We will tighten stock controls to reduce the stock variations.
In a prior report dated 25th March 2025 the physical stock counted, Bread had a -66.75 loaves, and poly bags had -173 pcs
Previous
The internal audit team, in collaboration with the branch team, conducted a physical stock take on 10th June 2025

The physical stock count revealed some variances, mainly in bread, poly bags, gunny bags and raw materials. Some of variances have been addressed by the branch management.  Overall, controls are in place but should be further improved to aid in minimizing future variances.
Operations/Production Department
The exercise aimed to verify the accuracy of stock records, assess stock management controls, and identify any variances.

attributes.title: 2. Bread weight
attributes.description: Results from the sample indicated instances of underweight across all the varieties tested except on 600CTW.  The table below illustrates the findings:
attributes.recommendation: Bread weight control needs to be enhanced from dividing area to packing section to ensure that loaves packed are of the required standard weight.
attributes.effect: Underweight bread dispatched to market exposes the company to risk of penalties if they are intercepted by the weight and measures officials.

value: The underweight issue is due to high moisture loss caused by prolonged baking time and overcooling. We will put in more checkups on weight to avoid underweights.
We will try our best to maintain the required bread weight standards.
In prior audit cases of underweight were noted as follows:- 800CTW-17%, 600CTW-10%, 400 CTW-10%, 200 Ml-6% & 400BR-1%.
Previous
A random sample of bread produced and packed in the branch was selected and weighed.
The branch did not comply with bread weight controls, indicating that controls are not sufficiently strong. Branch needs to strengthen bread controls to ensure weight compliance.
Operations/Production Department
The objective was to verify compliance with the permissible weight standards (e.g. 200g, 400g. 600g. 800g, and 1.5g) as prescribed by weight and measures department and the company internal policy.

attributes.title: 3. Bread Damages
attributes.description:
The audit covered the period from 1 May 2025 to 7 June 2025, and the following were noted: -

·     Production damage: Averaged at 0.24% of the production damage, which is above the allowable level of 0.20%. The deviation resulted in a revenue loss of Ksh.23,574.37

·       Market damage: - Averaged at 0.54% of the total sales, the level exceeded the standard threshold of 0.50%, which resulted in revenue loss of Ksh.36,621.13.

· Further it was noted that mini shop damage contributed 34.08% of the market damage.

Table 1 Analysis of Production Damages

                     Table 2 Analysis of Market Damages
attributes.recommendation:
The branch management should control damage by ensuring bread produced is of standard quality by following set procedures to reduce production damage and market returns.

Management should investigate the root cause of the high return rates from mini shops, considering that these outlets receive bread directly from the branch and sell directly to customers. The investigation should aim to establish whether the returns are due to operational issues, handling practices, or possible misreporting.
attributes.effect:
Excess damage surpassing the set threshold results in a revenue loss to the company.

High rate of mini shops returns indicates weak control of handing bread at mini shop.

value: We are trying our best to reduce bread damage in the branch by ensuring we produce quality bread.
I will advise the manager and supervisors to ensure all set production procedures set to reduce cases of damage.  During the period our mixer had issues too.
During the prior audit it was noted that production damage was 0.23% of the total production while market damages were 0.44% of the total sales
Previous
An analysis of production and market damage was calculated.
From the analysis bread damages exceeded the set limit and this indicates that branch was not following up the production procedures.
Operations/Production Department
The Production and market damages were analysed to establish whether they were within the set limit of 0.20% and 0.50% respectively.

attributes.title: 4.	Damages sent to Ingredients’ Balance Analysis
attributes.description: The reconciliation revealed a significant variance between the total damages recorded at the branch level and those sent to the ingredients department. The total branch-level damages amounted to 11,427.50 loaves, whereas the total received by the ingredients department was 11,679.75 loaves, resulting in a positive variance of +252.25 loaves.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should establish and enforce measures to weigh and verify daily bread damage, ensuring that accurate records are maintained to reflect the true status of both declared and available damages.
attributes.effect: The excess bread damage sent to the ingredients department indicates that the branch has unreported damages that were not disclosed. The undisclosed damages, valued at Ksh. 13,369.25, highlights potential weaknesses in internal damage reporting and stock accountability processes.

value: We will ensure that damage captured on the SAP systems matches with the damages records.

On several occasions during damage verification exercises, I observed that actual damages weighed at the branch exceeded the quantities recorded in the manager’s book. This discrepancy indicates the presence of excess damages that destroyed without the knowledge or approval of the branch manager or supervisor.

Further, the branch is facing a challenge of limited storage space for storing damages, resulting in damaged stock being stored in open, unsecured areas.
N/A
Previous
A reconciliation exercise was carried out to verify the accuracy of bread damage quantities sent to the ingredients department.
The controls for recording and sending bread damages were strong and operating effectively.
Operations/Production Department

The objective was to determine whether the quantities sent to ingredients department corresponded with damages captured in the SAP systems as production damages, market damages, oven damages, bread deductions, and supermarket return. The audit covered the period from 1st May 2025 to 7th June 2025.

attributes.title: 5. Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
Below are a summary of the findings.

v  Utto consumption stood at 100 %.

v  The average yield was 191.85 loaves per bag.

v  Average production was 161.71 bags per day; this represents 89.84% of the set target of 180 bags.

v  No remix was noted during the audit period.

v There was accuracy of figures transferred from mixing chart summary to cash flow for the period audited.

The table shows the summary findings of the mixing chart
attributes.recommendation:
The branch should strive to ensure that they attain their target.

The branch should record the actual yield, therefore the BOM should be adjusted to reflect the actual production.
attributes.effect: Production target was below the set target, and this indicates that the branch capacity was underutilized.

value:
Production is below the set target because of the power outage because of the lower voltage of transformers.

We have changed transformers, and we hope we will achieve the set target.

The production target was not achieved due to frequent power outages, which disrupted operations. However, a more powerful transformer has since been installed, and it is anticipated that production target will improve significantly going forward.
N/A
An analysis of both mixing chart and mixing chart summary were done for a period of 41 days from 1st May 2025 to 7th June 2025.
Production procedures were found to be followed to the letter, in full compliance with established guidelines.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to assess whether raw materials consumption was in line with the Bill of materials (BOM) and whether set yield and quality standards were met.

attributes.title: 6. Understatement of the Yield
attributes.description:
During the spot check instances of understated production yields, particularly in Unit 2 were noted and the following were the findings: -

  • 800g Bread:

    • Actual production: 99 loaves

    • Recorded production: 97 loaves

    • Variance: 2 loaves (understated)

  • 600 CTW:

    • Actual production: 129 loaves

    • Recorded production: 126 loaves

    • Variance: 3 loaves (understated)
attributes.recommendation: The branch should ensure that actual production yield is accurately recorded based on physical output, and not merely aligned with the Bill of Materials (BOM). In cases where the BOM yield is lower than actual production, the branch should formally communicate to the accounts department and initiate adjustments. This will promote transparency, accountability, and more accurate performance.
attributes.effect: When excess production is not recorded, it results in a loss of potential revenue, as the unrecorded products cannot be officially accounted for, tracked, or sold.

value: Excess production could be remix, however we will make follow up on this issue.

The under-recording of yield is not acceptable and goes against established operational procedures. This issue will be followed up and addressed with the responsible teams to ensure that all production yields are accurately recorded going forward. Measures will also be put in place to enhance accountability and prevent recurrence.
N/A
A spot check was conducted on the recording of mixing charts on 8th and 10th June 2025.

The audit established that production yields were not accurately recorded in the mixing charts, as evidenced by discrepancies noted during spot checks conducted on 8th and 10th June 2025.

It was also noted that the branch appears to record yields based on the Bill of Materials (BOM) rather than actual production output.

To uphold transparency and accountability, the branch must consistently record actual yields, and any misalignment with the BOM should be formally communicated for adjustment.
Operations/Production Department
The objective of the audit was to verify the accuracy of production yield recording in the mixing charts.

attributes.title: 7.	Cash Count Analysis.
attributes.description:
At time of audit the cash balance was zero. The cash had been collected by G4s.

There were two pending IOU’s amounting to Ksh.4,000 for vehicle inspection.

At the time of the spot check there was no cash for NSSF or SHA
attributes.recommendation: The branch should continue to advocate for good cash asset controls.
attributes.effect: The spot check confirmed that cash controls were strong and functioning effectively, with clear evidence of adherence to company policies and procedures.

value: Cash was well controlled.
Fair controlled. I will be following up to ensure the IOUs are cleared.
In a prior audit report, all the cash was well accounted for.
Previous
A spot check was carried out in the branch’s cash office on 8th June 2025.
Cash controls were strong and working effectively.
Operations/Production Department
To verify the accuracy of cash transactions, assess compliance with cash handling procedures, and ensure proper documentation and safekeeping of cash at the branch level.

attributes.title: 8. Production Efficiency
attributes.description: It was noted that the production efficiency was 4.53 bags per production worker, and the standard rate achieved was within the set limit. The table below illustrates the findings.
attributes.recommendation: The controls on production workers should be maintained.
attributes.effect: Production efficiency was within the set target, and this indicates that the labour force was properly utilized.

value: We will maintain
This is recommendable and it should be maintained.
In prior audit production efficiency stood at 4.47 bags per production worker.
Production efficiency was calculated for a period of 38 days from 1st May 2025 to 7th June 2025.
The audit revealed that branch effectively and efficiently utilize the labour force.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.50 bags

attributes.title: 9.	Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
The average packing efficiency for the sampled period was 94.73 crates per packer per day, which is below the set target.

The summary of the calculation is presented below:
attributes.recommendation: Hiring of Packers shift wise should be guided by the number of bags produced in the prior shift. This will enable the branch to achieve set target.
attributes.effect: The packing efficiency fell below the set standard of 97 crates per packer, indicating suboptimal utilization of the labour hence an extra labour costs amounting to Ksh. 17,328 which directly affects profitability.

value: Packing efficiency was affected by power outages. However, we are trying our best to achieve set target.
Compared to the previous period, there has been some improvement. We will continue to optimize slicer operations to ensure we meet the set production targets.
In prior audit packing efficiency stood at 93.80 crates per slicers
Previous
Packing Efficiency was computed for a period of 37 days from 1st May 2025 to 7th June 2025.
Internal audit found that the branch effectively and efficiently utilize labour force.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to determine whether the set company standard of 97 crates per packer was being achieved.

attributes.title: 10. Vehicles fuel consumption analysis
attributes.description:
From the analysis it was found that all route vehicles fuel consumption was within the set standard with the exception to three vehicles (KCG 046R, KDH 135W & KCF 478E) which consumed more fuel.

KBZ 516T & KDP 497R fuel should be adjusted to match the actual consumption has they had saved fuel.
attributes.recommendation: A follow-up should be made on all vehicles which actual fuel consumption rate is more than the set KPI and a retest be done to get the accurate standard rate of fuel consumption
attributes.effect: Fuel consumption was well controlled with the exception to three vehicles which used more fuel hence an extra cost of distributing bread.

value: We will follow up to ensure the three vehicles’ fuel is controlled by requesting a retest.
Noted, we will follow up to ensure fuel is well controlled by requesting for retest.
In prior audit it was noted that all the vehicles were within the set fuel consumption standards
Previous
An analysis of fuel consumption was done for the month of May 2025.

We noted that fuel consumption of some of the vehicles was within the set standard and this indicated effective fuel usage controls, three vehicles fuel consumption was above the set standard. This overconsumption indicates gaps in monitoring and control mechanisms related to fuel usage.

The presence of both compliant and non-compliant fuel consumption patterns points to inconsistencies in enforcement of fuel management controls. Strengthening monitoring systems and implementing real-time fuel tracking solutions are necessary to ensure uniform compliance across the entire fleet.
Operations/Production Department

The primary objectives were to evaluate compliance with fuel efficiency standards, identify any areas of inefficiency, and recommend strategies for reducing fuel consumption and associated costs. The audit encompassed a comprehensive review of fuel records, maintenance logs, and related policies and procedures.
